chapter1_1.text: Sai "Go is a 2-player game using a board & stones.
Black and white play alternatively, and who takes more territory wins.
Sai "Whatever size, the rules are the same.
Hikaru "To beginners like @NAME@, I suggest starting with 9x9.
Sai "Right. 9x9 is smaller, thus easier to understand.
Stones come in black and white, one for each player.
They can also be played on the @STRESSRED@edges@ENDSTRESS@.
Sai "A game proceeds by black and white playing alternatively.

chapter1_2.text: Sai "In go, the player with more territory wins.
For example, these black stones surround some territory for black.
To count ji, count surrounded intersections, not the stones.
How many moku does white have?
Sorry, that's not correct. Let's count together.
Next, how to count ji on the edges.
How many moku does white have?
Next, how to count ji on the corners.
How many moku does white have?
Sai "Use edges and corners to take more territory with fewer stones.
Remember not to count the stones.

chapter1_3.text: Sai "Capture opponent stones by surrouding them with your stones.
Let's see some capturing in action.
I play black. First, look at this white stone.
It has 4 intersections adjacent to it.
When black plays on all 4, the white stone is captured.
That is, when opponent stones have no way to escape, they are captured.
It's the same with more than 1 stone.
Sai "Now let's capture on the edge.
Like before, looking at intersections...
There are 3 adjacent to the stone.
When black plays on all 3, the white stone is captured.
It's the same with more than 1 stone.
Hikaru "How about on the corner?
Like before, looking at intersections...
Now there are only 2 adjacent to the stone, right?
Black playing on both captures the white stone.
Of course, the same with more than 1 stone.
So? Wherever you play, blocking opponent's escape is the same, right?
Sai "Heh heh, that's right.
However, beginners may forget how to capture on edges and corners.
Also, don't just focus on capturing, also try to avoid being captured.
Lastly, on how captured stones are used.
Captured stones are called @STRESSRED@prisoners@ENDSTRESS@.
Prisoners reduce your opponent's territory at end of games.

chapter1_4.text: Sai "Before a game, play order and handicap are decided.
The order is called teban.
When black plays, it's called black's turn. Same with white's turn.
A game begins at black's turn.
To decide play order, since the first player has an advantage,
usually the weaker player plays black, the stronger white.
When players differ in skill level, handicap can be applied.
Let's look at how to place handicap stones.
In a handicapped game, black begins with 2 or more stones.
This is very advantageous to black.
Number of stones is decided by difference in skill.
For an example, look at this game.
Here, black gets 4 handicap stones.
These 4 stones count as 1 move, so it's white's turn next.
If no handicap stones are placed, it's called an @STRESSRED@even game@ENDSTRESS@.
In even games, use @STRESSRED@nigiri@ENDSTRESS@ to decide sides.
Nigiri is to guess odd or even. Correct guess allows you to choose side.
Let's do a nigiri for real.
Hikaru, please demonstrate nigiri.
Hikaru "OK, I'll nigiri!
Odd or even
Correct! You take black.
Missed! I'll go black.
Sai "After play order is decided, since black has an advantage,
In an even game, a handicap, @STRESSRED@komi@ENDSTRESS@, is given to white.
Komi means additional territory.
With komi of 5.5 moku, white starts the game with 5.5 moku.
Komi is not visible, and only takes effect when counting territory.
The half-moku also prevents draw games.
With handicaps, anyone can play together.

chapter1_5.text: Sai "When neither player is able to gain any additional territory,
a game ends.
This is called @STRESSRED@shuugyoku@ENDSTRESS@.
Then, after counting, the one with more territory wins.
Hikaru "If you find a game hopeless, you can also surrender.
In go, this is called to @STRESSRED@resign@ENDSTRESS@.
The resigning player loses regardless of territory.
Sai "Now, after a game ends, before territory is counted,
there are things that must be done.
First, areas that belong to neither player are filled.
These intersections are called @STRESSRED@dame@ENDSTRESS@.
Then, dead opponent stones in your territory become prisoners.
Finally, put prisoners into opponent territory.
Hikaru "That's how prisoners reduce opponent territory.
Sai "Now we are almost ready to start counting...
but the board is so messy it's difficult to count.
So we move stones without affecting territory, to make it easier.
This is @STRESSRED@seichi@ENDSTRESS@.
Hikaru "See, this is easier, right?
Sai "Now we can finally count.
Who wins in this game? Do you know?
Who wins
Black
White
Correct! Let's count. First, black territory.
Incorrect. Let's count. First, black territory.
Black 25moku
White 16moku
Sai "... and the answer is black wins.
What if white has komi of 5.5 moku?
With komi, white adds the komi to their territory.
So, white has 16+5.5=21.5 moku.
Here black still wins even with komi.
Hikaru "By the way, when both players have the same moku, it's a @STRESSRED@draw@ENDSTRESS@.
It won't happen when there's komi.
Sai "Do you understand winning and losing now?
Ending a game and counting may be difficult at first.
But you will understand it with practice, so don't give up.

chapter2_1.text: Sai "@STRESSRED@Illegal plays@ENDSTRESS@ are places you cannot play.
For example, since black fully surrounds here,
a white stone played here will immediately be captured.
Like this, you can't play where you'll be immediately captured.
Sai "Now, a question.
With these black stones, what is an illegal play for white?
Choose from A/B/C
Correct! You really got it.
Sorry, incorrect. I'll explain.
Stones played at B will be immediately captured by black.
Thus, B is the illegal play.
Hikaru "Can you answer this one?
What is an illegal play for white?
Sai "Wow that's correct! @NAME@ is learning fast.
Hmmm, no. That was difficult. Sai, explain.
Sai "A stone at A will be immediately captured.
So A is the illegal play.
Exceptions exist to this rule
This seems to be an illegal play for black.
However black playing here captures 2 white stones.
Like that, if you can capture opponent stones, that's the exception,
and the play is legal.
Sai "You will see such exceptions frequently.
They come in many forms so take caution to not miss any.

chapter2_2.text: Sai "When you are one move away from capturing,
it's an @STRESSRED@atari@ENDSTRESS@.
Let's see an atari in action.
I play black. First let's play here.
Next I can play here to capture white. That last stone caused an atari.
It's the same if I first play here.
So does white just await capture?
No, here white is able to escape.
Let's say black plays here.
If white then plays here, black cannot surround white with the next move.
So white was able to escape.
Sai "Now let's look at this question about atari.
I play white. Where do I play to cause atari?
Correct!
Sorry, not correct. I'll explain.
With A or B, white cannot capture with the next move. That's not atari.
With C, white can capture black in corner with the next move.
Next, how about this.
I play white. Where should I play to capture black?
Correct!
Sorry, not correct. I'll explain.
It seems I can play at either A or C to atari.
Let's say I play at A.
Black's turn. Black can play C to escape from atari.
Not only that, black now puts white in atari.
So what if I played at C?
Even if black plays at A to escape, they're still captured.
So, the correct answer is for white to play at C.
Sai "Do you understand atari now?
Remember to not only look out for atari,
but also try to atari your opponent.
Hikaru "Let me teach you some good stuff.
Say it's black's turn.
If black plays here, it's atari alright...
but white can play here to escape, right?
But if black plays here, then it's 2 ataris at the same time.
If white defends this stone, that one is captured.
Defend that one, and this one is captured.
Hikaru "Like that, making 2 ataris with 1 move is a @STRESSRED@double atari@ENDSTRESS@.
It's an easy technique in real games, so remember that.

chapter2_3.text: In this situation, first black captures white like this.
Then white may play here to capture black.
Such capturing at the same place is a kou.
If this goes on forever, the game will never end.
So, there's a rule against such immediate capture.
Here, if black made the first capture,
then it's illegal for white to immediately capture.
Hikaru "But it's OK to capture that after one move elsewhere.
Then black also plays elsewhere. When it's white's turn again,
and now white is unable to capture.
Sai "It's a complex rule so pay attention until you get used to it.

chapter2_4.text: Sai "On the board, some stones are @STRESSRED@alive@ENDSTRESS@, some are @STRESSRED@dead@ENDSTRESS@.
When stones can absolutely not be captured, they are alive.
Likewise, stones that will inevitably be captured are dead.
Now I'll explain what formations make stones alive or dead.
Stones normally get captured when surrounded, but not the alive stones.
For example, here black is surrounded by white...
but white cannot play at arrows, for they are illegal plays.
Thus, these black stones cannot be captured, and they are alive.
This group of black stones has 2 holes in them.
It's called @STRESSRED@two eyes@ENDSTRESS@.
When you make two eyes, your stones cannot be captured, and are alive.
Then, how about this.
This intersection seems to be an illegal play for white,
but the exception applies, and white is allowed to play here.
Thus, all black stones are captured.
These stones would eventually be captured, so they are dead.
Sai "Question.
Black's turn. Are these black stones alive?
Is black alive or dead
Alive
Dead
Correct!
Incorrect. Let me explain.
If black plays here,
white can play here to capture black.
If black plays here,
white can play here to capture black.
So these black stones are dead.
Hikaru "There are basic forms of life and death.
They are useful so I'll teach you some!
Here two eyes are made on the edge. Black stones are alive.
Here two eyes are made on the corner.
Hikaru "Now how about this?
White's turn. Is black alive or dead?
Alive
Dead
Yes!
Nope! I'll explain.
If white plays here
black makes 2 eyes like this.
If white plays here
thats also 2 eyes.
So black is alive no matter what.
Sai "Do you understand how two eyes means life now?
Now let's look at forms that are not 2 eyes.
This formation seems similar to the two eyes shown earlier...
Let's see what happens if it's white's turn.
White playing here captures one black stone.
Then black cannot escape no matter where they play.
Hikaru "Don't forget kou!
Sai "Finally, white plays here
and captures all black stones!
So, black seems to have two eyes,
but is actually dead.
Such formations that seem to be but are not two eyes
are called @STRESSRED@false eyes@ENDSTRESS@. They do not make stones alive.
Be careful not to confuse eyes with false eyes.
Sai "Do you understand life and death now?
Life and death can be difficult at first,
but the basics are all explained.
Remembering the basic rules will help you understand faster.

chapter2_5.text: Sai "@STRESSRED@Seki@ENDSTRESS@ is when neither player can capture without being captured.
I'll show what a seki looks like.
This is a seki. Let's start with black.
Black plays here to atari white on the inside.
So what if black plays here?
It's the same. All black stones are captured.
White plays here to atari black.
and white stones are still captured.
Sai "Such situations when neither can play are called seki.
It's not counted toward either player's territory.
Pay attention to not accidentaly make sekis.

chapter3_1.text: Sai "From now I'll explain how actual games proceed.
First, about @STRESSRED@sente@ENDSTRESS@ and @STRESSRED@gote@ENDSTRESS@.
Sente is to play on the attacking side.
And gote is to play on the defending or escaping side.
Though black starts a game and initially has sente,
Sente and gote may switch during a game.
For example, it's now black's turn.
Black ataris
and white escapes atari like this.
Here black has sente, and white has gote.
On the contrary, here it's white's turn.
White ataris
and black escapes atari like this.
Here white has sente, and black has gote.
Sai "These are the basics.
Since sente has an advantage, inspect the whole board before playing.
Next let's see sente and gote switch.
In this example, black plays here to atari white.
Right now black has sente and white has gote.
However white plays here instead of defends.
Black captures this white stone
and then white ataris black.
Now white has sente and black has gote.
Hikaru "Like that, sente and gote are switched.
When playing in gote, look for chances to take sente.
Looking ahead before playing is what makes go so fun.
Sai "Now I'll show some techniques to take sente from opponent.
Here black attacks white on the edge.
Black has sente.
How can white play to take sente?
White plays here to prevent black from invading.
Playing on the diagonal to suppress the opponent is called @STRESSRED@hane@ENDSTRESS@.
Black plays here to block white.
White plays here out of atari.
This move @STRESSRED@connected@ENDSTRESS@ white stones.
Black is in danger so plays here
and the fight ends for now.
And it's white's turn. Now white has taken sente from black.
Using hane then connect is called @STRESSRED@hane-connect@ENDSTRESS@.
Hikaru "Hane-connect can do a lot, like take sente or harden territory.
Be sure to learn that by heart.

chapter3_2.text: Sai "A game can be divided into opening, middlegame and endgame.
Laying out stones at the beginning is @STRESSRED@fuseki@ENDSTRESS@.
You make foundations of territory and prepare for middlegame.
Let's see how to play the opening.
First, decide where do you want your territory to be. Remember that
making territory at edges and corners is more efficient.
You need 7 stones to get 9 moku on the corner,
11 on edges,
and 16 in the middle.
That's a lot of stones needed to make territory in the middle.
Hikaru "That's why it's easier on the edges and corners.
Do you understand now?
If not, you'll lose a lot of moku.
So Sai, what are some good places to play at opening?
Sai "Let me explain.
First there's @STRESSRED@3-3@ENDSTRESS@. It's on the 3rd row from either direction.
3-3 makes it easy to take a corner.
But it's not advantageous to fights in the middle.
Next is the @STRESSRED@star@ENDSTRESS@. It's on the 4th row from either direction.
They have a nice balance between corner and middle.
But the corner may be taken from you if opponent plays 3-3.
Finally, @STRESSRED@komoku@ENDSTRESS@, or 3-4.
3-4 covers the corner and responds to the middle
so it's considered the most steady play.
Sai "Since black and white plays alternatively,
your opponent will also take positions such as 3-3, star and 3-4.
However, watch out for such situations.
Here black has occupied the right side.
White's turn.
White attacks right corner!
Black tries to capture white to protect the corner.
But white instead of defending, expands territory.
Black takes the chance to capture white.
As a result, black reinforced its territory alright,
but white has taken a lot more territory.
Like that, if you focus on small areas you'll lose territory.
Also, early capturing fights make it difficult to establish territory.
Avoid capturing attempts and play with the whole board in mind.
Sai "After the opening stage, middlegame starts.
That is when fights occur.
A good opening will gain you advantages in middlegame.
So think carefully while playing.

chapter3_3.text: Sai "Middlegame is when both players fight to death for territory.
You must use the opening stones to take territory efficiently.
Now I'll show some basic ways to play middlegame.
Since you surround intersections to take them,
it's good to connect your stones.
Here the black stones are @STRESSRED@connected@ENDSTRESS@.
Different from the white stones seperated in 2 areas,
for black its easier to make territory when connected.
It's also harder to be captured.
Now, it's black's turn. Where should black play?
Correct! Let me explain a bit.
Too bad! Incorrect. I'll explain.
By playing B, black stones are connected horizontally
and it also prevents white from connecting vertically.
Preventing opponent's connection is to @STRESSRED@cut@ENDSTRESS@.
Hikaru "That was horizontal & vertical connection.
Then, how about diagonal?
These black stones seem to be diagonally connected, right?
However they are not really connected yet.
See how they are not directly adjacent to each other?
So, being diagonally connected isn't really being connected.
For example, white may play here...
and now black stones are cut.
In this case black failed to connect.
But when white plays here,
black can actually connect like this!
Different from earlier, right? Now the stones are properly adjacent.
So diagonally connected stones can be connected like that.
Hikaru "Let's see if you really understand!
Black's turn. How can black connect their stones?
Wow, that's correct!
Hmm, no! I'll explain so look closely.
Let's think about where white would play.
Here white would play at A, cutting the top-right black stones.
But if black plays A, then white cannot cut black by playing B or C.
So black should play A to prevent white from doing the same.
Sai "That's right. There are times when you should look at multiple plays ahead.
How can white connect the 2 stones at top and 2 at bottom?
You may want to play here but that's not correct.
Black plays here
and white gets cut by black stones.
Actually it's here.
This formation is called @STRESSRED@bamboo joint@ENDSTRESS@ for its shape.
So what if black plays inside?
White connects every stone.
Sai "Knowing how to connect will make you better at making territory.
Remember that diagonally connected stones may be cut.

chapter3_4.text: Sai "In middlegame, stones will clash in persuit of territory.
Attacking opponent territory or stones
and escaping from opponent attacks will happen a lot.
If you know how to escape, you'll naturally know how to prevent escape.
So let's see how to escape.
To escape, you must constantly prevent capture from oncoming stones.
Here, white has black in atari.
Black now looks at ways to escape. Here there's only one
so black plays here.
Now there are 3 ways to escape.
And white now needs 3 more stones to capture black.
But if black plays here
white can play here to capture black.
If you only have 1 way of escape, you will eventually be captured.
So you should always have 2 or more ways to go in order to escape.
Hikaru "In games the situation gets complex, so escaping can be difficult.
However, remember the basics, and you should be all right.
Sai, let's move on to attacking.
Sai "Understood.
Let's show how to attack stones on the edge.
Black plays here to atari white.
White plays here to escape, but gets in another atari.
When the chase goes to the corner, white can no longer escape.
So black is able to capture white.
Black's first play is important.
If the atari was like this,
white is able to play here and escape.
Sai "Question.
How to capture the white stone close to the edge?
Choose from A/B
Correct! You got it.
Sadly, incorrect. I'll explain.
In such situations, the direction of chasing is important.
If black plays at A to atari,
white can play here to escape.
Let's see the correct answer.
Black plays here to atari.
White plays here to escape atari...
but gets in atari again.
Even if white plays here, they cannot escape.
And now black captures white.
Sai "Another one.
To capture white in the middle, where should black play?
Correct! You are good at this.
Sorry, incorrect. Let's think about it.
Here we should also think about the direction to chase white.
Playing B is an atari,
but white can play here to escape.
Let's see the correct answer.
Black plays A to atari.
White plays here, but has no way to escape.
And now black captures white.
Like that, choosing a direction to chase the opponent is important.
Sai "Do you understand attack and escape?
Ways to escape is important in either case. Don't overlook it.

chapter3_5.text: Sai "After middlegame fights, some territory are not fully surrounded
so endgame is when borders of territories are finalized.
After that, the winner can be determined.
I'll explain how to play endgame.
Finalizing borders is called @STRESSRED@yose@ENDSTRESS@.
For example, on the left, territories are clearly identified,
but it's still unclear who owns the right corner.
So we use stones from opening and middlegame, strive to connect them,
expand our territory and shrink opponent's. That's yose.
A major yose that gains 10 moku or more is called
a @STRESSRED@large yose@ENDSTRESS@.
Sai "After large yoses come delicate @STRESSRED@small yoses@ENDSTRESS@.
Small yoses yield 5 moku or less, but are still important.
Let's start with small yose.
Look at this situation.
Both black and white have their territory almost finalized.
If black plays here
and white plays here, the border is finalized
and both players have 9 moku.
If black plays here instead
then white must prevent black's invasion.
So white plays here
and black plays here in response to atari.
Now the border is finalized.
Black has 9 moku, white has 8 moku.
Black has shrunk white territory!
Hikaru "Next I'll show something that's easily overlooked.
Here, you'd think all territories are final, right?
Actually, black has a weak spot.
If white plays here, black is in atari, right?
It's a disaster if the stone is captured.
Thus, black has its territory shrunk by white's invasion.
That's why black should play here before white
to prevent such invasion.
Look out for diagonally connected stones like these.
Sai "After yose, when neither player can play anymore, the game ends.
Yose is important in finalizing territory.
One failed small yose may overturn the final result,
so pay attention and play carefully.

chapter4_1.text: Sai "Now I'll show some tesujis.
Tesujis are frequently used strategies in go.
I'll focus on tesujis on capturing.
Hikaru "Tesujis are like math formulas, highly useful once remembered.
Sai "First, the @STRESSRED@ladder@ENDSTRESS@.
Ladder is to chase the opponent towards the edge.
Let's chase this white stone.
First, black plays here, atari.
White escapes atari like this.
Then black ataris the 2 white stone.
White escapes, but is soon in atari again.
Once the chase reaches the edge, all white stones are captured.
Ladder is often used in games so remember it.
Hikaru "Beginners often play the first move wrongly.
For example, what if black plays here?
White plays here
and has 2 ways to escape despite black's play.
Thus, black is unable to capture white.
Sai "That's right. The first play in ladder is very important.
In reality, the ladder may fail even after the correct first play.
Let's see what happens if there's a white stone here.
White gets connected so black is unable to atari anymore.
This is a failed ladder. Here this white stone played a critical role.
The stone that prevents ladder is called @STRESSRED@ladder-breaker@ENDSTRESS@.
Sai "Finally, a question on ladder.
White's turn. Where should white play?
Choose from A/B
Correct.
Incorrect.
If white plays B, black can play at A and escape.
If white plays A, white can continue to atari black.
So A is the answer.
Sai "Ladders can be overlooked if you aren't used to it.
Remember to look for chances so as to not waste them.

chapter4_2.text: Sai "@STRESSRED@Net@ENDSTRESS@ is to ambush and capture opponent stones.
Let's capture this stone with net.
First, play black here. Though it's not an atari,
it prevents white's connection.
White plays here
and black ataris.
Even if white tries to escape,
they're still captured by black.
What happens if we use ladder instead?
Black ataris directly.
White escapes from atari.
Then another atari, white escapes again.
It's good up to now, but after black plays here...
white connects all stones
and escapes cleanly.
That's a failed ladder. A net should be used instead to ambush.
Hikaru "Do you understand net now? Then, a question.
Black's turn. How to play a net?
Correct! You got it! I'll explain anyway.
Nope! I'll explain.
If black plays A or B, white can escape.
At C, white is captured no matter what.
So C is correct.
Hikaru "Know when to ladder or net!

chapter4_3.text: Sai "Next is @STRESSRED@snapback@ENDSTRESS@.
Snapback is to let opponent capture some stones,
and then capture more opponent stones.
Black's turn. How can black capture the 2 white stones?
First, black plays here, atari.
White can play here to escape.
What if black plays here?
Since white is in atari, white plays here to capture black.
Observe that the 3 white stones are in atari again.
So black now plays here to capture the 3 white stones.
That is snapback.
Hikaru "The first move sacrifices some stones.
But in return you capture more opponent stones. Feels good right?
Sai "The tesujis are getting complex.
Let's see this question.
White's turn. How to capture 2 black stones?
Correct!
Incorrect. Let me explain.
At A, black can play B and avoid capture.
At B, black plays A to capture one stone,
but white then captures 3 black stones.
So B is correct.
Sai "Snapback is the strategy that breaks bones by cutting meat.

chapter4_4.text: Sai "I'll explain @STRESSRED@oiotoshi@ENDSTRESS@.
Oiotoshi is to repeatedly atari until capture.
It's a bit hard, but a very satisfying tesuji.
For example, look at this board.
Black plays here, atari.
In defense, white plays here and captures black.
From now on an oiotoshi starts.
First play here to atari white.
White plays here to escape,
but black then plays here, capturing 6 white stones.
This is oiotoshi.
But if black plays wrongly, the oiotoshi will fail.
If black plays here,
then white plays here, connects and escapes.
Even if black attempts to surround white,
white can play here
to capture black and escape.
This is a failed oiotoshi.
To play oiotoshi, you must think several plays ahead.
Hikaru "This is different from snapback.
It's hard, so get a better feeling with this question.
White's turn. To capture black with oiotoshi, where should white play?
Choose from A/B
Correct! Good job.
Hmm. Nope. It's hard, after all.
If white plays A,
black can play B, and white cannot capture.
At B, despite losing 1 stone
white plays here
to capture black stones like this.
So B is correct.
Hikaru "You can invade opponent territory despite their seeming eye.
Think carefully until the very end.

chapter4_5.text: Sai "Finally, an interesting tesuji called @STRESSRED@crane's nest@ENDSTRESS@.
Here, are the 3 white stones able to escape?
Actually, no. Let's think about why not.
But black can block the exit...
So what if white plays 1 intersection ahead?
and white plays here to atari black.
Black instead of escapes, plays here.
white has no way to escape anymore.
Hikaru "It's called that because the white stones
at the end of this tesuji look like a crane's nest.

controls.text: Sai "Now I'll explain the controls in the game.
Let's do it with a real game.
Hikaru, are you ready?
Hikaru "All right, as practice, I'll take black.
Hikaru "Then it's @NAME@'s turn. @DPAD@ moves cursor, @ABUTTON@ to play.
Play anywhere you like
Hikaru "Right, like that.
Sai "Then, I'll explain some help functions in games.
Hikaru "One function is the @STRESSRED@territory analyzer@ENDSTRESS@.
Another is @STRESSRED@hint@ENDSTRESS@ that suggests plays.
First, territory analyzer. Press @RBUTTON@.
Press@RBUTTON@
Analyzing
B 32m-W 19m-Komi 5.5m-LosingBy 7.5m
Hikaru "So? Knowing the mokus is convenient, right?
Next is hint. Press @LBUTTON@.
Press@LBUTTON@
Working
7|3 5|6 2|8 suggested
Hikaru "It gives 3 suggested plays right?
If hint is set to @STRESSRED@choose-3@ENDSTRESS@, up to 3 suggestions will be given.
Which to choose is up to @NAME@.
If hint is set to @STRESSRED@best@ENDSTRESS@, it only suggests the best play.
No more confusion!
Try using it on various occations.
Sai "Both functions can be cancelled by pressing @BBUTTON@.
Now I'll explain some other functions that help in games.
Hikaru "Other help functions include
@STRESSRED@realtime territory analysis@ENDSTRESS@, and
@STRESSRED@atari warning@ENDSTRESS@ that shows opponent ataris.
First, realtime territory analysis. Instead of me talking,
why not experience for yourself. Try moving the cursor around.
Hikaru "Is it easy to see how to expand territory now?
However, being real time, it's not very accurate.
Use @LBUTTON@ when you want an accurate report.
Then, atari warning. I'll demonstrate with an atari.
Hikaru "It shows you when you are in atari like that,
so you won't ever get captured by surprise.
Sai "Finally, on how to end a game.
Hikaru "A game ends when neither players want to make any move.
You can @STRESSRED@propose endgame@ENDSTRESS@ when you want to.
Press @SELECTBUTTON@ to show the menu and we'll look at it.
Press select
Hikaru "Choose @STRESSRED@propose endgame@ENDSTRESS@ from here to propose end of game.
Game ends when opponent agrees.
Alternatively, consecutive @STRESSRED@passes@ENDSTRESS@ also end a game.
But it's usually safer to @STRESSRED@propose endgame@ENDSTRESS@.
Sai "Right. When opponent denies your @STRESSRED@propose endgame@ENDSTRESS@,
you don't lose your turn.
Now, @NAME@ should know everything needed to play a game.
Just as a reminder, there's a control cheatsheet.
Sai "Press @STARTBUTTON@ to view it anytime.
Refer to it whenever you forget the controls.
The controls aren't hard at all once you get used to it,
so just play lots of games!

intro.text: Teacher "We have a transfer student.
Everyone, please be friendly with @NAME@.
Hikaru "Yo @NAME@. Me? I'm Shindou Hikaru. Nice to meet you!
Feel free to ask me anything you wanna know.
Hikaru "Huh? This weird looking person besides me? You can see him?
Sai "Hikaru! This person... can see me?!
Hikaru "This is Sai. He's sort of a spirit.
But he loves go and is not a bad guy.
Still, this is troubling...
Sai "It's not troubling at all, Hikaru.
Perhaps this person has special powers just like Hikaru.
@NAME@, you play go, right?
Sai "... what? You don't?
Hikaru, what do we do?
Hikaru "Well not much we can do if they don't play.
It's not like Sai floats around you all the time anyway.
However, @NAME@. Though it gets hard at times, go is a great game!
I know! Why don't you play go with us! It's decided!
Sai "Agreed!
Hikaru "At any rate, come play at my place!

firstVisit.text: Hikaru "@NAME@, welcome.
Now Sai will teach you everything about go.
Sai "Let me introduce myself.
I am Fujiwara no Sai, a go instructor from Heian Period.
However after a certain incident, I left the world before achieving mastery.
Then my wandering soul met Hikaru and was able to return.
And now I meet you...
It might also be determined by fate.
And now I'll teach you everything about go.

subsequentVisit.text: Sai "Oh you are back. That must mean you want a refresher on go.
That's right, it's good to reinforce the basics.
Let's get started.

afterSolvingMediumTsumego.text: I heard you've been doing tsumego at the internet cafe?
My grandpa also likes tsumego and has made a lot of his own.
You can go to him if you want harder problems.

afterReadingTutorial1stTime.text: Didn't get everything? That's normal, with all that content.
I know! Let's go to the go classroom. That's the best place to start!
Sai "Don't worry, I will accompany you.

afterReadingTutorial.text: Sai "And that was the basics of go.
Next you need practice. Do your best!

firstVisit.text: Akari "Hello! Oh it's @NAME@, Hikaru told me about you at school.
I'm Fujisaki Akari. Hiya.
So you are also new to go?
I also started recently, but I'm still bad at it.
I know! Let's play a beginners' game!

subsequentVisit.text: Akari "Hi @NAME@. Wanna play with me again?
Yes
No

afterFirstWin.text: Akari "Huh? Aren't you Touya?
Akira "Good morning. I was asked to teach at this classroom.
And I put this on schedule thinking I could meet Shindou...
Akari "Oh. I think Hikaru is still at school...
He usually plays at the classroom there.
Akira "I see...
Akari "Also, this is @NAME@. He plays with Hikaru.
Still beginner, though.
Akira "With Shindou?
I'm Touya Akira. Rival to Shindou, we both seek mastery of go.
And to think he plays with beginners like you...
Akari "But, Hikaru says @NAME@ has potential.
Akira "Go is no child play. The road ahead is endless and steep.
If you also seek mastery, we will meet again.
Akira "Please tell Shindou that I will defeat him next time.

afterSubsequentGame.text: Akari "Are you getting used to go already?
I can be your opponent any time.

beforeRecruitingMitani.text: Akari "Oh hi! What, play at the practice match?
I can't. It's played by gender right?
Akari "The one who solved the poster problem? I know, it's Mitani in class 3.
Where he is? Hmm. He always leaves immediately after school so I don't know.
That's right, his sister works part-time at an internet cafe downtown.
Maybe she knows where Mitani is?

firstVisit.text: Hikaru "Hey it's @NAME@. What, you met Touya Akira?
Sai "He will defeat Hikaru, he said.
Well, the Hikaru he knows actually played with my help, though.
Hikaru "Isn't that guy great.
Not many people are as focused on go as him.
He's my target. Someday I will catch up and be better than him.
Sai "Hikaru! How about a game with @NAME@?
Hikaru "That's right! @NAME@, let's play a game right now!
Sai "Hikaru, since it's @NAME@'s first game on their own,
please give some handicap.
Hikaru "I'll give 4 stones on 9x9. Game on!

subsequentVisit.text: Hikaru "Yo @NAME@! Are you free? How about a game?
Like before, I'll give 4 stones on 9x9.
I give 2 stones on 9x9 this time.

win.text: Hikaru "Woah, I lost again? You are really good.
Sai "Hikaru, don't relax! You'll get overtaken!

lose.text: Hikaru "Heh heh. Too bad. But you are getting better.

afterFirstWin.text: Hikaru "Oh no, I lost. You are pretty good.
Sai "Yeah, good work.
@NAME@ is improving fast.
Hikaru "By the way would you like to join the go club?
Actually we are quite short handed.
Sai "Good idea. @NAME@ can practice to get even stronger.
Hikaru "Well, don't think too hard about it. Why not just come for a visit!

firstVisit.text: Tsutsui "Ah @NAME@. I am Tsutsui Kimihiro. Shindou told me about you.
You know the rules already? Then how about tsumego?
In tsumego, you look at a board with placed stones,
and answer which is the best next move. It's like a puzzle.
Want to do some? Get 4 out of 5 correct to pass easy tsumego.

subsequentVisit.text: Tsutsui "Yo. Wanna do tsumego? I got some good ones. 4 out of 5 to pass.

success.text: Tsutsui "You are getting the hang of this.
Wanna challenge harder ones next time?

failure.text: Beginners are welcome at the club so come again.

afterFirstWin.text: Hikaru "Yo, you are doing good! Now you can enter the match.
Tsutsui "Huh? Is this person joining the club?
Hikaru "Of course! You are joining, right?
Well actually we have a practice match with Kaio.
It's a 5-on-5 team match, however...
as you can see, we just barely had 3 members.
Tsutsui "Kaio has a strong go club, so they have lots of players.
Hikaru "Tsutsui, there's no use saying that.
Let's focus on recruiting members before the match.
Tsutsui "Right. Because of that, @NAME@ helped a lot by joining us.
The fate of the club also depends on it...
Hikaru "Is that so?
Tsutsui "Yes. Our club hasn't had even practice matches at all.
If we lose this practice match, the club may be disbanded.
Sai "That's terrible!
Hikaru "Then @NAME@ please enter the match no matter what.
With that said, we still only have 3. We need 2 more members.
Though you just joined, let's work together to recruit them!
Sai "It's all right! There must be lots of people interested in go.
I'll also help. Let's look together!
Tsutsui "I put up a recruiting poster earlier with a hard tsumego,
and someone solved it. If only we know who that is...
Hikaru "Is there anyone who knows about it?

beforeRecruitingKaga.text: Tsutsui "Got recruits? Well, it is hard.
Actually I know this potential recruit.
Tsutsui "@NAME@, you've found one already? Nice, one to go.
Actually I know another potential recruit.
Hikaru "Why didn't you say so earlier! Who is it?
Hikaru "Ack, him? I don't like him, with his bad mouth.
Tsutsui "But he is really good at go.
@NAME@, the club's fate depends on the match.
I'm terribly sorry but please go to shogi club and recruit Kaga.

afterRecruitingKaga.text: Hikaru "@NAME@! You defeated Kaga? Great job!
Kaga "Hmph. I won't lose at an even game!
Shindou, you don't want to take Touya Akira?
When I get stronger, as strong as him,
that's when I'll take on him.
Tsutsui "Then, it seems @NAME@ will be Touya Akira's opponent.
Kaga "What, we give up against Touya?
Tsutsui "No we don't. @NAME@ defeated you two.
I think that's enough to defeat Touya.
Mitani "Isn't it just practice? I don't care who just hurry up and decide.
Sai "@NAME@ is all right. Do what you've been doing and you will win.
So keep on practicing and play more games!

firstVisit.text: M.Sis "Welcome. Oh, Yuuki's friend?
M.Sis "Where Yuuki is?
...he's been to the go salon lately.
Sai "Salon?
M.Sis "He seems to play with adults everyday.
I told him to play with friends at times, but...
Huh? The salon's location? Why?
M.Sis "So you want Yuuki to join the go club.
He's a bit weird so are you just gonna ask directly...?
M.Sis "I know. You're good at go, right?
Yuuki went to the salon so he can play at a higher level.
If you show that your club is better than the salon,
then Yuuki may be persuaded?
Sai "Looks like this one is hard to deal with...
M.Sis "Then, try some tsumego on this computer.
Get 4 outta 5 and I'll tell you where the salon is.

subsequentVisit.text: M.Sis "Welcome. Wanna challenge tsumego again? 4 out of 5 to pass.

success.text: M.Sis "Good job. Is this software too easy for you?

failure.text: Whenever I'm here you are free to come and play again.

afterFirstWin.text: M.Sis "Wow! You are really good.
That should be able to persuade Yuuki.
Go salon is to the north. Take care of Yuuki.

afterFirstLoss.text: M.Sis "Hmm. I can't tell you the location like this.
You need more strength than that to persuade Yuuki.
Come again when you get better.

firstVisit.text: Sai "So this is the go salon. Looks a bit scary, but let's get in.
What kind of go do they play here? I can't wait to see!
Mitani "What you want?
Yes I am Mitani... and?
Mitani "Go club? Not going. I don't like chummy go.
I'd rather sleep than play that kinda low-level go.
Sai "Exactly as his sister said.
@NAME@, show him what you've got.
Mitani "What, a game? Didn't I say I don't play low-level go?
Sai "It's all right. @NAME@ won't lose. Have faith.
Mitani "How insistent. Fine. Just one game.
9x9, komi of 5.5 moku, so it ends fast. Okay?

subsequentVisit.text: Mitani "What, you again? Wanna play, then?
Worry not, I am playing that match.
Let's nigiri this time. 9x9, komi 5.5 moku.

subsequentVisitBeforeFirstWin.text: Mitani "You again? Just when will you leave?
I really don't wanna be your opponent. Get seated, now.

win.text: Mitani "Damn...
But I won't lose next time!

lose.text: Mitani "You lost. You sure about the Kaio match?

afterFirstWin.text: Mitani "...Fine. I take that low-level stuff back.
With guys like you, a go club doesn't sound that bad.
...Now that I play, I will defeat Kaio. You must do the same!

afterFirstLoss.text: It's a waste of time playing with you. Go home.

unused1.text: I didn't lose. Don't you worry about the match!

unused2.text: Let's play again. I will win this time!

firstVisit.text: Kaga "What, play the match againt Kaio? You know who you're talking to?
Tsutsui sent you? Is that weakling too scared?
Sai "@NAME@, chill.
Kaga "I'm pretty good at go. Defeat me and I may think about the match.
Sai "This person does seem strong.
It won't be an easy win, even for @NAME@.
Kaga "I'm confident I'll win, though.
What, first time on 13x13? Fine, just this time I'll give 2 handicap stones.
In return, if I win, you go and jump into a winter pool!

subsequentVisit.text: Kaga "Hey @NAME@! Wanna join the shogi club?
What, a game of go? Then if I win, you join the shogi club, all right?
Let's do 13x13, komi 5.5 moku.

subsequentVisitBeforeFirstWin.text: Kaga "You just have to keep challenging me huh?
It's the same no matter what, but you do have guts so I will play.
13x13, 2 handicap stones. No way am I giving any more.

win.text: Kaga "Tch, I lost again... you are pretty good. Wanna play a game of shogi?

lose.text: Kaga "So, you ready to join the shogi club?
Kaga "I see. Don't worry. If you don't wanna join, I won't force it.
But you are welcomed if you change your mind!

afterFirstWin.text: Kaga "Damn you're better than seemed. As promised I will play the match.
Sai "Congrats! That was a great game filled with @NAME@'s wills.
Kaga "You've got quite the guts.
It's a pity you're in go club. Wanna join the shogi club?

afterFirstLoss.text: Kaga "It's over. I'll be waiting at the winter pool.
Sai "Too bad. But that game showed possibilities. You may win next time.
By the way what is a "puu"?
Kaga "Now, be gone. Or I'll really kick you into the pool!

unused1.text: Kaga "Meh. Even with 2 handicap stones you can be proud that we came to a draw.
Fine, I'll forget about the pool. Be gone!

unused2.text: Kaga "Well that was that. Just being able to compete with me is a big deal.

firstVisit.text: Akira "Where is Shindou? Is he not the captain!?
I thought I could play with Shindou in this match!
The match is meaningless to me now...
Hikaru "Not yet, Touya. @NAME@ is a very skilled player.
Akira "I heard you just started playing go.
To think you could defeat me...
Mitani "Hey cut the chatter and just start playing.
Akira "...understood.
If Shindou says so, you must have quite the strength.
Sai "@NAME@, you can do it. Just stay calm!
Akira "But I won't hold back. You also fight with all you have!

win.text: Akira "I lost...
It felt coarse but I saw some great moves.
You may be a talented player indeed.
You and I, we pursue the same goal.
Let's battle again in the future.
Sai "Yes I always knew it.
Kaga "Quite cool of you defeating that Touya!
Tsutsui "Now Haze go club lives on.
Mitani "I'm shocked. You are... awesome.
Hikaru "Wow! You are talented after all, defeating Touya!
I also have a new rival now.
Sai "@NAME@, you have grown strong.
You can do just well without me now.
Please continue learning go even without me.
By doing that, you can become even stronger.
Let's play a game when we meet again.

drawOrLose.text: Akira "Even with good moves at times, you are still not mature.
Akira "Sadly a winner couldn't be determined.
However, if we pursue the same goal,
Though the outcome is sad, surely @NAME@ can improve from this loss.
Though there wasn't a winner, surely @NAME@ can improve from this game.
You have much skill. From now on you can keep learning on your own.
By doing that, someday you will defeat him.
Sai "Aah, I also wanna play! Please!

firstVisit.text: Heihachi "Oh! You are Hikaru's friend, right?
Came to learn go? Good for you.
Then try some tsumego that I made.
Get 4 out of 5 correct to pass.

success.text: I'll come up with harder problems so come again.

failure.text: Keep learning go every day. Come again.

firstVisit.text: Kaneko "Hey it's @NAME@. What's up?
By the way @NAME@, I heard you joined the go club? I also go there at times.
Speaking of that, I haven't played in a while.
Since we are here, how about a game?
Let's play on 13x13. I'll take black, komi is 5.5 moku.

subsequentVisit.text: Kaneko "Back again? All right, I'll be your opponent.
Kaneko "13x13, komi 5.5 moku. Of course I play black.
Kaneko "How about 2 handicap stones this time?

win.text: Kaneko "Hmm. I'm not in the zone anymore.
@NAME@ is better than I thought. But I won't lose again.

draw.text: Kaneko "A draw, huh. Won't happen again.

lose.text: Kaneko "Yeah like that. You should train harder for the match.

firstVisit.text: Kishimoto "Hm? You're from Haze... Got a minute?
So you defeated our Touya...
Touya is outstanding even in our go club. Yet he loses to a beginner
like you in a practice match. It's unbelievable.
May I test if you really have such strength?
I am president of Kaio go club. I'll give 4 stones on 19x19.

subsequentVisit.text: Kishimoto "Somehow we meet again.
I do want a game with you... what do you say?
We had a good game. I give 4 stones this time, too.
You are a strong player. From now I'll only give 2 stones.

win.text: Kishimoto "Hmm. I lost in a blink... it was right to give up on pro.

lose.text: Kishimoto "You have some skills but not enough to defeat Touya.
Did I push you too hard? Or did you
not give it your all for some reason?

afterFirstWin.text: Kishimoto "I see. That's why Touya lost.
Gotta work hard for the next match.

firstVisit.text: Meijin "Akira is not home... you are the kid that fell Akira?
I inquire your strength. Sit.
Sai "He has a strong aura. @NAME@, fight with your heart.
Meijin "I am Meijin. You play black. Komi is -10.5 moku.

subsequentVisit.text: Meijin "It's you. Sit if you seek a game.
As before, you take black, komi -10.5 moku.
You have strength. We play even from now.

win.text: Meijin "Hmm... good talent. You should go pro, the sooner the better.
Then we play on even fields.

lose.text: Meijin "Hmm, so it ended. However, you made interesting moves.

game0.text: Akari "@NAME@ takes black. Komi is 5.5 moku.
Let's begin.
Sai "Now I will play a demo game for @NAME@.
I will show where to play, but don't just be a puppet.
Please feel the flow of each move.
First, we play on the corner to lay out territories.
Let's start from the top-right corner.
Sai "This place is called 3-3.
Akari "OK. I'll take left edge.
Sai "Akari-chan played on the bottom-left star. Let's play on bottom edge, then.
Akari "Top-left is vacant. Go!
Akari "Now left side is mine, right?
Sai "Akari-chan just played on the top-left komoku.
These are important places so remember them, @NAME@.
Now we contact the bottom-left white to expand.
Akari "Ah! Contact play! Then I'll also...
Sai "With that, the fight on the bottom ends for now.
Let's move to the middle.
Sai "Our territory is taking shape.
Now I want to attack bottom-left corner.
@NAME@, where is the best play?
Sai "Hmm, too bad. Being too aggresive, the stone is isolated.
Sai "Hmm, no. While it's a good play,
we can reduce more opponent territory.
Sai "That's right. The best play is here.
It expands our territory on the bottom-right,
and reduces opponent territory on the left.
We just played diagonally next to our stone. It's called hane.
Sai "It expands our territory on the bottom-right,
and reduces opponent territory on the left.
We just played diagonally next to our stone. It's called hane.
Akari "Gotta prevent invasion on bottom-left...
Sai "Opponent's play blocked our attack.
Sai "To prevent being cut by opponent stones,
we need to connect.
Akari "Ah, connect. I'll also do that.
Sai "She also connected. That series of moves is hane-connect.
Hane-connect is always used when finalizing borders.
Sai "Let's finalize the border now.
Sai "The bottom-left fight is over.
Time for yose. First, finalize the uncertain borders.
Akari "Gotta expand my territory...
Sai "We prevent opponent from invading,
that's the basic of yose.
Akari "I think this is a good play.
Sai "Opponent played hane. Now it's @NAME@'s defense.
Where to play next?
Sai "That makes one black stone captured!
Sai "White can now invade, causing us a great loss.
Sai "Playing here stops opponent from invading.
Sai "That's right. Playing here stops opponent from invading.
Then it's hane-connect like before.
Akari "Now just fill dames right?
Sai "Filling dames ends a game.
Places belonging to neither player are filled.
@NAME@, fill bottom-left corner.
Akari "Game has ended, right? Let's tidy up.
Akari "@NAME@ has 34 moku.
Akari "With komi, I have 18+5.5=23.5 moku.
@NAME@ won by 10.5 moku!
Aww, what a big loss.

game1.text: Akari "@NAME@ takes black. Komi is 5.5 moku.
Sai "Now I will play a demo game for @NAME@.
I will show where to play, but don't just be a puppet.
Please feel the flow of each move.
Akari "I'll extend from center to left!
Akari "Ah I'm in atari. But it's not ended yet!
attack the center and expand to bottom-right.

but white can cut by playing here.
white can cut by playing here.

I'll block here and attack top-right.
Let's return to and take bottom-left.
but they are already in dead end.
Akari "I must capture this stone or I lose all white stones!
Sai "White ataris black on left but it's too late!
Akari "Ow, I lost so many stones...
Akari "I'll use 1 stone on left to attack.
What is the best move for black?
We should keep the stones connected.
After our atari white will capture 1 stone.
Sai "We should keep the stones connected.
Akari "Ah, atari. Glad I saw that.
we connect with top-left and expand further!
Ahh, losing the left side was painful.

Let's begin.

We can't just sit and watch.

At these times we calm down and respond.

Now let's deal with the bottom.

Putting in prisoners.
Akari "Tidying up.
Akari "@NAME@ has 27 moku.

@NAME@ won by 11.5 moku!
I lost.
But go is really fun!

This jump made more territory for white
in the top-right corner. In these situations,
we can disturb them by trying to prevent

As the game concludes, this stone is of vital importance,
